an2.32:0.2: The Chapter on the Peaceful Mind
an2.32:1.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you the level of the untrue person and the level of the true person.
an2.32:1.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
an2.32:2.1: “What is the level of the untrue person?
an2.32:2.2: The untrue person is ungrateful and thankless,
an2.32:2.3: for the wicked only know how to be ungrateful and thankless.
an2.32:2.4: It is totally the level of an untrue person to be ungrateful and thankless.
an2.32:2.5: The true person is grateful and thankful,
an2.32:2.6: for the virtuous only know how to be grateful and thankful.
an2.32:2.7: It is totally the level of a true person to be grateful and thankful.”
an2.33:1.1: “Mendicants, I say that these two individuals cannot easily be repaid.
an2.33:1.4: You would not have done enough to repay your mother and father even if you were to carry your mother around on one shoulder and your father on the other, and if you lived like this for a hundred years, and if you were to anoint, massage, bathe, and rub them;
an2.33:1.5: and even if they were to defecate and urinate right there.
an2.33:1.6: Even if you were to establish your mother and father as supreme monarchs of this great earth, abounding in the seven treasures, you would still not have done enough to repay them.
an2.33:1.8: Parents are very helpful to their children: they raise them, nurture them, and show them the world.
an2.33:1.9: But you have done enough, more than enough, to repay them if you encourage, settle, and ground unfaithful parents in faith, unethical parents in ethical conduct, stingy parents in generosity, or ignorant parents in wisdom.”
an2.34:1.1: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
an2.34:1.2: “What does the worthy Gotama teach? What does he explain?”
an2.34:1.4: “But in what way does the worthy Gotama teach action and inaction?”
an2.34:2.1: “I teach inaction regarding bad bodily, verbal, and mental conduct, and the many kinds of unskillful things.
an2.34:2.2: I teach action regarding good bodily, verbal, and mental conduct, and the many kinds of skillful things.
an2.34:2.3: This is the kind of action and inaction that I teach.”
an2.34:3.1: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! … From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
an2.35:1.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,
an2.35:1.2: “How many in the world are worthy of a religious donation? And where should a gift be given?”
an2.35:1.3: “Householder, there are two in the world who are worthy of a religious donation:
an2.35:1.5: These two in the world are worthy of a religious donation, and that’s where you should give a gift.”
an2.35:2.1: That is what the Buddha said.
an2.35:2.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
an2.35:3.1: “In this world, the trainee and the adept,
an2.35:3.2: are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.
an2.35:3.5: This is the field for sponsors of sacrifice—
an2.35:3.6: what’s given here is very fruitful.”
an2.36:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an2.36:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
an2.36:1.8: “I will teach you about an individual fettered internally and one fettered externally.
an2.36:1.9: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
an2.36:2.2: It’s a mendicant who is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an2.36:2.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an2.36:2.4: When they pass away from there, they’re a returner, who comes back to this place.
an2.36:2.5: This is called an individual who is fettered internally, a returner, who comes back to this place.
an2.36:3.1: Who is an individual fettered externally?
an2.36:3.2: It’s a mendicant who is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an2.36:3.3: They enter and remain in a certain peaceful state of freed mind.
an2.36:3.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an2.36:3.5: When they pass away from there, they’re a non-returner, not coming back to this place.
an2.36:3.6: This is called an individual who is fettered externally, a non-returner, who does not come back to this place.
an2.36:4.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical … they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an2.36:4.2: They simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding sensual pleasures.
an2.36:4.3: They simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives.
an2.36:4.4: They practice for the ending of craving.
an2.36:4.5: They practice for the ending of greed.
an2.36:4.6: When their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an2.36:4.7: When they pass away from there, they are non-returners, not coming back to this place.
an2.36:4.8: This is called an individual who is fettered externally, a non-returner, who does not come back to this place.”
an2.36:5.1: Then several peaceful-minded deities went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to the Buddha,
an2.36:5.2: “Sir, Venerable Sāriputta is in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery, where he is teaching the mendicants about an individual with internal fetters and one with external fetters.
an2.36:5.4: Sir, please go to Venerable Sāriputta out of sympathy.”
an2.36:5.6: Then the Buddha, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery, in front of Sāriputta.
an2.36:5.7: He sat on the seat spread out.
an2.36:5.8: Sāriputta bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
an2.36:6.1: “Just now, Sāriputta, several peaceful-minded deities came up to me, bowed, and stood to one side. Those deities said to me:
an2.36:6.2: ‘Sir, Venerable Sāriputta is in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery, where he is teaching the mendicants about an individual with internal fetters and one with external fetters.
an2.36:6.4: Sir, please go to Venerable Sāriputta out of sympathy.’
an2.36:6.5: Those deities, though they number ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or sixty, can stand on the point of a needle without bumping up against each other.
an2.36:6.7: ‘Surely those deities, since so many of them can stand on the point of a needle without bumping up against each other, must have developed their minds in that place.’
an2.36:6.8: But you should not see it like this.
an2.36:6.9: It was right here that those deities developed their minds.
an2.36:6.10: So you should train like this:
an2.36:6.11: ‘We shall have peaceful faculties and peaceful minds.’
an2.36:6.13: When your faculties and mind are peaceful, your acts of body, speech, and mind will be peaceful, thinking:
an2.36:6.14: ‘We shall present the gift of peace to our spiritual companions.’
an2.36:6.16: Those wanderers of other religions, Sāriputta, who have not heard this exposition of the teaching are lost.”
an2.37:1.2: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying at Varaṇā, on the bank of the Kaddama Lake.
an2.37:1.3: Then the brahmin Ārāmadaṇḍa went up to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him.
an2.37:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Mahākaccāna:
an2.37:1.5: “What is the cause, worthy Kaccāna, what is the reason why aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders?”
an2.37:1.6: “It is because of their insistence on sensual desire, their shackles, avarice, and attachment, that aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders.”
an2.37:2.1: “What is the cause, worthy Kaccāna, what is the reason why ascetics fight with ascetics?”
an2.37:2.2: “It is because of their insistence on views, their shackles, avarice, and attachment, that ascetics fight with ascetics.”
an2.37:3.1: “Worthy Kaccāna, is there anyone in the world who has gone beyond the insistence on sensual desire and the insistence on views?”
an2.37:4.1: “Who in the world has gone beyond the insistence on sensual desire and the insistence on views?”
an2.37:4.2: “In the eastern lands there is a city named Sāvatthī.
an2.37:4.3: There the Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an2.37:4.4: He, brahmin, has gone beyond the insistence on sensual desire and the insistence on views.”
an2.37:5.1: When this was said, the brahmin Ārāmadaṇḍa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
an2.37:6.1: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
an2.37:7.1: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
an2.37:8.1: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
an2.37:9.1: He who has gone beyond the insistence on sensual desire and the insistence on views.
an2.37:10.2: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kaccāna has made the teaching clear in many ways.
an2.37:10.3: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
an2.37:10.4: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
an2.38:1.1: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying near Madhurā, in the Nut Grass Grove.
an2.38:1.2: Then the brahmin Kandarāyana went up to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him … He sat down to one side and said to Mahākaccāna:
an2.38:1.3: “I have heard, worthy Kaccāna, that the ascetic Kaccāna doesn’t bow to old brahmins, the elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.
an2.38:1.4: And this is indeed the case,
an2.38:1.5: for the ascetic Kaccāna does not bow to old brahmins, elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.
an2.38:1.6: This is not appropriate, worthy Kaccāna.”
an2.38:2.1: “There is the stage of an elder and the stage of youth as explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an2.38:2.2: If an elder, though eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old, still dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more,
an2.38:2.3: they are reckoned as a child, not a senior.
an2.38:2.4: If a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life,
an2.38:2.5: does not dwell in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more,
an2.38:2.6: they are reckoned as astute, a senior.”
an2.38:3.1: When this was said, the brahmin Kandarāyana got up from his seat, placed his robe over one shoulder, and bowed with his head at the feet of the young mendicants, saying,
an2.38:3.2: “The good fellows are elders, at the stage of the elder;
an2.38:3.3: we are youths, at the stage of youth.
an2.38:4.1: Excellent, worthy Kaccāna! … From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
an2.39:1.1: “At a time when bandits are strong, kings are weak.
an2.39:1.2: Then the king is not at ease when going out or coming back or when touring the provinces.
an2.39:1.3: The brahmins and householders, likewise, are not at ease when going out or coming back, or when inspecting their business activities.
an2.39:1.4: In the same way, at a time when bad mendicants are strong, good-hearted mendicants are weak.
an2.39:1.5: Then the good-hearted mendicants continually adhere to silence in the midst of the Saṅgha, or they stay in the borderlands.
an2.39:1.6: This is for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.
an2.39:2.1: At a time when kings are strong, bandits are weak.
an2.39:2.2: Then the king is at ease when going out or coming back or when inspecting the provinces.
an2.39:2.3: The brahmins and householders, likewise, are at ease when going out or coming back, or when inspecting their business activities.
an2.39:2.4: In the same way, at a time when good-hearted mendicants are strong, bad mendicants are weak.
an2.39:2.5: Then the bad mendicants continually adhere to silence in the midst of the Saṅgha, or they leave for some place or other.
an2.39:2.6: This is for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
an2.40:1.1: “Mendicants, I don’t praise wrong practice for these two, for laypeople and renunciates.
an2.40:1.2: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in completing the system of the skillful teaching.
an2.40:2.1: I praise right practice for these two, for laypeople and renunciates.
an2.40:2.2: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in completing the system of the skillful teaching.”
an2.41:1.1: “Mendicants, by memorizing the discourses incorrectly, taking only a semblance of the phrasing, some mendicants shut out the meaning and the teaching. They act for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.
an2.41:1.2: They brim with much wickedness and make the true teaching disappear.
an2.41:2.1: But by memorizing the discourses well, not taking only a semblance of the phrasing, some mendicants reinforce the meaning and the teaching. They act for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness  of gods and humans.
an2.41:2.2: They brim with much merit and make the true teaching continue.”
